review_blob: Growler from the brewery.  Black and thick with a small white brown head.  Strong aroma of chocolate and cherries.  Tastes like a chocolate covered cherry in a glass.  Another wonderful Haymarket beer.

Dark orangy body, small white head.  Cloudy.  Aroma of grapefruit and hops.  Some alcohol.  Delicious hoppy but slightly sweet flavor, almost a ruby red grapefruit flavor.  Alcohol is apparent.  Excellent beer.
Dark orange body with a frothy white head.  Nose of citrus, hops, and some sweetness.  Good balance of hops and bready malts.

22 oz bomber.  Dark brown, almost black body with almost no tan head.  Aroma is delightfully chocolaty with a hint of coffee.  Flavor is quite sweet, but not cloying, heavy on the chocolate, with a bit of coffee bitterness, and some hop bite in the finish.  The 11% ABV is well hidden.  Palate is smooth and moderately thick.  This probably isnt the most complex beer Ive tasted, but if you like sweet imperial stouts, and I do, its a wonderful beer.

Brown body white head.  Decent aroma of toasted malts and chocolate.  Flavor has some nice roasted malt notes with chocolate and coffee, maybe a bit of nuttiness.  Palate is thick enough, but not syrupy.  I liked this one, but its not particularly memorable.

22 oz bomber.  Beautiful reddish gold body with a small white head.  Aroma is hoppy with a fruity sweetness.  Flavor was hoppier than I expected, balanced by subtle sweet bread and caramel notes.  Light carbonation and quite nice to drink.

22 oz bomber.  Straw yellow body with a big white head.  Light, fruity aroma.  Flavor is wheaty, a bit fruity, slightly sweet, but overall very subtle.  It reminded me of a Belgian Tripel crossed with an American macro lager.  I tasted the Belgian style flavor, but I think this beer would be quite palatable to Joe Table down at the corner bar pounding the Buds....

22 oz bomber.  Very nice.  Red brown body with a good whitish head.  Aroma is very sweet, highlighted by bready malts.  Flavor is quite sweet, malty, bready, but not cloying at all.  A bit syrupy, but very drinkable.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 22oz bomber.  Pour looks like oil with a medium brownish head that quickly dissipated.  Nose had candy and molasses.  Flavor was more subtle and less sweet than i expected.  Its very nice, highlighted by chocolate, licorice, and a bitter hop/roasted malt finish.

22oz bomber.  Dark, dark brown pour with a brown white head, small to medium, with some staying power.  Nose wasnt much, but I did start it a bit too cold.  I got some citrus, not a lot else.  Flavor is quite nice, and fairly complex.  Good toasty chocolate, roasted malts, dark fruits, but well balanced with a citrusy hop flavor.  Good solid mouthfeel, not too syrupy, not too thin.  Quite a nice beer.

22 oz. bomber.  Poured a bright orange/gold with a small white head.  Aroma could almost have been grapefruit juice - citrus, citrus, citrus.  Flavor had a very nice hop bite, but little else. I almost felt like it was an American macrobrew with a hop finish.  Fairly tasty, easy to drink, but I didnt think it was anything special.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bottle.  Pours deep, dark, and syrupy, with a pretty large brown head that died down gradually.  Nose is chocolaty with dark fruits.  Taste is of chocolate and plums, cherries and roasted malts.  On first sip, I also noticed a lot of the alcohol, but on subsequent sips didnt notice nearly as much.  Very nice beer if you like imperial stouts (and I do!)

22 oz. bomber at Binnys in Elmwood Park.  Pours looking like peach nectar with a fluffy white head.  Nose is consistent with a fruity aroma mixed with hops.  Flavor is the same.  Very much a Three Floyds style of beer - which I would say is a good thing.  Smooth and delicious.  Note:  I tasted this before I knew what it was, and would never have guessed its classified as a Barley Wine.

Oily black with a small brown head.  Aroma is heavy on the bourbon, but with chocolate notes.  And I agree with thegreenroaster, the flavor hits with a blast of bourbon, is there any beer flavor there?  Tasty, but the bourbon and the stout arent married as well as in some bourbon barrel stouts (Goose Island, 3 Floyds).

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep black with a moderate brown head.  Aroma is slightly sweet with chocolate and toasted malts.  Flavor is nicely sweet, but not overpowering, with a toasty finish.  Palate is much lighter than I expected.  More of a drinking beer than a sipping beer, which is very nice, but quite different from what I expected.

Another winner from Three Floyds.  Orange body with a big whitish head.  Aroma of citrus with some surprising bready notes.  Flavor is full, and sweeter than I expected,  but not cloying at all.  Hoppiness is quite present, but not as biting as in many American IPAs.  Smooth palate - cant much taste the alcohol, but I can tell its there.  Very nice beer.

22 oz bomber.  Dark brown body with a chocolaty brown head.  Aroma is sweet with chocolate.  Flavor has a lot of chocolate, but not too much to overwhelm the stout.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Very nice beer.

22 oz bomber.  Pours like a bottle of orange syrup.  Aroma is sweet, thick, and stongly alcoholic.  Flavor is similar.  I found it a bit cloying, and strong in alcohol.  Not as subtle as a really good Belgian, but still a tasty beer.

500 ml bottle.  Darkish amber color with a large white head and a lot of sediment.  Aroma is a bit hoppy and a bit sweet.  Taste was an interesting blend of Scottish Ale style malty sweetness and IPA hoppiness.  Tasty, but didnt seem to fit the IPA to me.

Pours a light orange gold with a medium white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is slightly hoppy with a strong brewery character to it.  Nice bready flavor with a good dose of hops.  Clean and crisp.

Bottle.  Cloudy light golden body with a big fizzy white head.  Slightly sweet aroma with some fruity notes.  Flavor is similar, light,  with peaches and bananas, and a sizable amount of carbonation that calms down as it warms (yes, I admit I started it too cold).

Bottle.  Copper body with almost no head.  Sweet malty aroma of what I suppose is raisins.  Flavor is quite sweet and syrupy, full of raisins and baking bread, with just a note of carbonation.  Hides the alcohol well, but you can tell its strong.

Bottle.  Packs a wallop.  A really nice, (as they say) drinkable, super heavily hopped IIPA.  Extreme hopiness comes off a bit harsh, lacking the balance of 3F Dreadnaught, and the alcohol is quite apparent, but this is a very nice beer.
Bottle.  Not bad, not great.  Tasted like an average pale ale with some ginger in the nose and the taste.  Id drink it again, but I wouldnt go out of my way to find it.

Bottle.  Very nice.  Dark brown-black body with a large brown head.  A sweet but not syrupy aroma with chocolate notes.  Very smooth tasting with the chocolate taste well ingrained in the beer, rather than laid on top.  Alcohol well hidden.
beer_name: Left Hand Wake Up Dead Imperial Stout - Barrel-Aged

review_blob: None of the awful skunkyl taste of many mass produced light lagers, but not much flavor either.
beer_name: Rock Bottom Indianapolis Circle City Light

review_blob: Bottle.  Dark brown black body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of chocolate with some sticky sweetness.  Flavor was surprisingly good and vibrant.  Bittersweet chocolate, not too sweet.  I enjoyed this one.
22 oz bottle.  Big white headish on an amber body.  Nice blend of hops and sweet, fruity malts.  Alcohol well hidden.

Very nice.  Ruby reddish brown body with a big (but quickly dissipating) head.  Aroma was chock full of fruits, from peaches and grapefruit to figs and prunes.  Flavor is a bit fruity and bready, but light and not too sweet.  Maybe not as nuanced as some Belgians Ive had, but very good.

Darkish brown body with a medium brownish white head.  Aroma is a combination of cocoa and molasses, not very pungent.  Flavor is similar with a light hoppiness, a delicate molassesy sweetness and a hint of cocoa.  A nice, drinkable porter.
beer_name: Great Divide St. Bridgets Porter (St. Brigids)

review_blob: 750 ml bottle.  Ruby body with a big off-white head.  Aroma is slight, but with notes of peaches and toffee.  Flavor is initially sweet with fruit and caramels, ending with a bitter finish.
Now rather common and standardized, but this is a decent tasting beer.  Not worth seeking out, but quite a nice session beer, and one of my favorite offerings from Sam Adams.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours with a cloudy, dark ruby body and a small, creamy off-white head.  Nose is a very interesting & nice blend of dark fruit, bready malts, and a citrusy grapefruit aroma.  Flavor nicely blends dark, sweet caramel maltiness with a grapefruity hoppiness.  Finished with a strong hop bite that seemed a bit incongruous.  Palate is very smooth, and alcohol well hidden.

Dark brown bottle with little head.  Aroma is sweet cocoa, and the flavor follows.  The cocoa is not well brewed into the beer, though, it tastes as if chocolate syrup was added later.  Not undrinkable, but I wouldnt buy it again.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a small bubble whitish head.  Thinner appearance than I expected.  Aroma is slightly sweet and very vinous.  Flavor is very smooth, with dark fruit sweetness and alot of red wine character.  Initial sip is rather more carbonated than I would have liked.
beer_name: Goose Island Bourbon Imperial Brown Goose (Bottled)

review_blob: Bottle.  Pours a very cloudy, very pale yellow with a small whitish head.  Not an appetizing looking beer.  Aroma is mild, with honey and vanilla.  Flavor is rather nice, though mild.  I tasted honey primarily with some vanilla and citrus fruit.  A decent beer, but not worth seeking out.

I wasnt impressed with this one - Founders is usually better.  Slight aroma was fruity with banana and bubblegum.  Flavor was similar, but cloyingly sweet with a chemical metallic flavor in there as well.  Cannot compete with the Belgians.

Bottle.  Cloudy pale yellow body with a smallish white head.  Aroma is fruity with bananas, peaches, some vanilla, and maybe a bit of citrus.  Flavor is similar, quite fruity.  I tasted a lot of banana, with peaches, vanilla, and yeast.  Moderately carbonated.  Quite a nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy neon yellow with a big white head.  Aroma is yeasty and spicy with a lot of different fruits - peaches, bananas, some citrus, even an ambrosia-like aroma.  In the tasting, the sweet fruit notes fade into the background as the spiciness takes over.      A nice beer.

Bottle.  Amber body with a golden tinge on closer inspection.  Small white head.  Malty aroma.  Flavor has a light caramel sweetness and a noticable hop presence. A nice beer, quite drinkable, but I hoped for more from 3Floyds.

Bottle.  Pours with a cloudy pale gold body and a medium white head.  Aroma is yeasty with some banana and bubble gum.  Flavor is light with yeasty and fruity notes.  Somewhat complex.  Thin body, refreshing.

beer_brewer_name: Brouwerij der Trappistenabdij De Achelse Kluis
review_blob: Bottle.  Cloudy yellow gold body with a lot of sediment and a towering fluffy white head - think meringue.  Aroma is sweet with yeast, peaches and pears, some lemon.  Flavor is more subtle but similar.  Body seems a bit fizzy to me.

Bottle.  Dark, but not thick reddish brown body with a small white brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, molasses, and some nice burnt malts.  Flavor is slightly sweet and somewhat toasty, with more going on than I first suspected.  Body is a little thin and fizzy.  A good but not great porter.

Bottle.  Pours with a dark brown, relatively thin body, and a small brown-white head.  Nose is faintly molassessy.  A very nice toasted malt flavor with just a hint of molasses sweetness.  Palate is thin, but not disappointingly so.  A very nice beer.
Bottle.  Cloudy yellow body with a significant head.  Aroma of banana, spice, and Belgian yeast.  Flavor is sweet with banana and spice, but a bit cloying.  Decent, but not my favorite.
Bottle.  Delicious.  Pours a ruby orange body with a small head.  Aroma is all peaches.  Tastes like a peach spritzer, but with more body and complexity of flavor.

Bottle.  Im not normally a wheat beer lover, but this is really good.  Cloudy yellow body with a big white head of small bubbles.  Aroma is light, and lemony with a bit of other fruit (peach?).  Flavor is light, but complex with lemon, banana, and spice.  Best hefeweizen Ive had.
Bottle.  Clear yellow golden body with a frothy white head.  Aroma is a bit skunky with some yeast.  Flavor is light and lemony, very dry.  A good pils, but not my favorite style.

22 oz bottle.  Velvety chestnut brown body with almost no head.  Aroma is quite sweet with maple syrup.  To be fair, this isnt my favorite style, but I found the flavor too syrupy sweet, almost like cough syrup.

Bottle.  Dark brown body with a good head.  Aroma is nice with chocolate and vanilla.  Flavor is bold, but tastes more like vanilla flavoring has been added to the beer, than like vanilla porter.  Not a bad beer, but I like it less the more I drink.
